docs.snippet: United States     Starting with the goalkeepers, Coach Steve Sampson was faced with several questions as the World Cup team gathered in Miami yesterday to start preparation for a critical World Cup qualifying game in El Salvador on Sunday.    Since...
docs.lead_paragraph: United States Starting with the goalkeepers, Coach Steve Sampson was faced with several questions as the World Cup team gathered in Miami yesterday to start preparation for a critical World Cup qualifying game in El Salvador on Sunday. Since Kasey Keller, the team's top goalkeeper, has been inactive for nearly a month after having minor elbow surgery, Sampson may start Brad Friedel.

docs.snippet: SOCCER     U.S. Eliminated      The United States was eliminated from the Under-20 World Cup yesterday with a 3-0 loss to Uruguay in the second round in Shah Alam, Malaysia. Marcelo Zalayeta scored twice before halftime on the United States goalie,...
docs.lead_paragraph: SOCCER U.S. Eliminated The United States was eliminated from the Under-20 World Cup yesterday with a 3-0 loss to Uruguay in the second round in Shah Alam, Malaysia. Marcelo Zalayeta scored twice before halftime on the United States goalie, Andy Kirk, and Nicolas Olivera had the final goal. The Americans, overwhelmed by Uruguay's speed and experience, had their best chance when Brian West hit the post in the 85th minute. The United States had defeated China, 1-0, to barely make it to the second round.
docs.abstract: US is eliminated from Under-20 World Cup soccer tournament with 3-0 loss to Uruguay in second round (S)

docs.snippet: TRACK AND FIELD    Greene Takes 100 Meters    Under a steady rain, Maurice Greene of the United States beat the world's best sprinters and won the 100 meters at the Athletissima Grand Prix meet in Lausanne, Switzerland, yesterday.
docs.lead_paragraph: TRACK AND FIELD Greene Takes 100 Meters Under a steady rain, Maurice Greene of the United States beat the world's best sprinters and won the 100 meters at the Athletissima Grand Prix meet in Lausanne, Switzerland, yesterday.
docs.abstract: Maurice Greene of US wins 100-meters race at Athletissima Grand Prix in Switzerland (S)

docs.snippet: GOLF     Robbins Extends Her Lead     Kelly Robbins shot a four-under 67 yesterday to extend her lead to six strokes in the Jamie Farr Kroger Classic in Sylvania, Ohio.    Robbins, who began the round with a two-stroke lead, had a tournament-record...
docs.lead_paragraph: GOLF Robbins Extends Her Lead Kelly Robbins shot a four-under 67 yesterday to extend her lead to six strokes in the Jamie Farr Kroger Classic in Sylvania, Ohio. Robbins, who began the round with a two-stroke lead, had a tournament-record 15-under 198 total on the Highland Meadows course. She also opened with a 67 and tied the course record Friday with a 64.
docs.abstract: Jamie Farr Kroger Classic women's golf tournament continues (S)

docs.snippet: The spacious sculpture garden at the Museum of Modern Art is an exquisite place. But it's awfully noisy. There's the passing traffic on West 54th Street, beyond the courtyard's wall, along with the Museum Tower's enormous air-conditioning vent, which...
docs.lead_paragraph: The spacious sculpture garden at the Museum of Modern Art is an exquisite place. But it's awfully noisy. There's the passing traffic on West 54th Street, beyond the courtyard's wall, along with the Museum Tower's enormous air-conditioning vent, which provides a constant swoosh of white noise. Yet for 11 years this has been the site of choice for Summergarden, the always interesting summertime concert series directed by Joel Sachs. One reason for his success is that, in keeping with the museum's mission and his own interests, Mr. Sachs draws his programs from the 20th century, avoiding quieter works in favor of raucously modern ones that can withstand the required amplification and fit in with the urban ambiance.
docs.abstract: Anthony Tommasini reviews Juilliard School students, led by Joel Sachs, in Summergarden concert at Museum of Modern Art; photo (M)

headline.main: Fireworks, Of a Sort, At Sculpture Garden

docs.snippet: Major League Soccer     The defending champion, D.C. United -- loaded with talent once more -- will have seven players in tomorrow night's All-Star Game at Giants Stadium.    With two victories over the weekend, United solidified its position atop...
docs.lead_paragraph: Major League Soccer The defending champion, D.C. United -- loaded with talent once more -- will have seven players in tomorrow night's All-Star Game at Giants Stadium. With two victories over the weekend, United solidified its position atop the Eastern Conference with 35 points from 13 victories in 17 games. United has been the dominant team in the Eastern Conference even though Marco Etcheverry and Jaime Moreno have missed the last six games because of World Cup qualifying and Copa America play with Bolivia.

docs.snippet: ''I DESCRIBE myself as someone who does everything you can do to make a living through dance, except strip,'' said Suki John, 38, who teaches salsa and ballet at schools, senior-citizen centers and studios in New York City. She also writes about...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''I DESCRIBE myself as someone who does everything you can do to make a living through dance, except strip,'' said Suki John, 38, who teaches salsa and ballet at schools, senior-citizen centers and studios in New York City. She also writes about dance and has worked as a choreographer for companies in Spain, Cuba, England, Finland and France. ''I am the definition of freelance,'' she said. A petite woman who appears to have zero percent body fat, Ms. John is a blur of energy, enthusiasm and plans. She rarely stays in one place for long. ''Suki has an incredible will to live fully,'' said Dr. Vera John Steiner, her mother.

docs.snippet: Thirty years after his assassination in the Bolivian mountains, Ernesto (Che) Guevara has captured the public fancy in ways he never intended. At least three biographies and several movies about Che will come out this year. The silk-screen Che icon...
docs.lead_paragraph: Thirty years after his assassination in the Bolivian mountains, Ernesto (Che) Guevara has captured the public fancy in ways he never intended. At least three biographies and several movies about Che will come out this year. The silk-screen Che icon with beard and beret now hawks compact discs, beer, Swatch watches, skis, designer dresses and a host of other products not traditionally associated with international Communism. Scientists have now found his body, one of seven skeletons in a pit in Bolivia, and brought it to Cuba. What would a Che alive today make of all this? He might not approve of the more crass commercialization of his name and image, but if the ideological migrations of his comrades are any indication, he would be firmly in the capitalist camp. Unlike his body, Che's politics remain entombed. Armed, leftist revolution is today found only in Cuba, and in a few violent but tiny bands in Colombia, Peru and now Mexico.
docs.abstract: Tina Rosenberg Editorial Notebook column contends that politics of late Cuban revolutionary Ernesto (Che) Guevara are long gone in Latin America; maintains that old leftist revolutionaries are now closer to European-style capitalism than anything Che ever preached (M)

docs.snippet: The MetroStars are losing in Major League Soccer, but they are creating news around the world. Yesterday, one day after signing Branco, the famous Brazilian defender, the MetroStars were trying to untangle themselves from an awkward situation...
docs.lead_paragraph: The MetroStars are losing in Major League Soccer, but they are creating news around the world. Yesterday, one day after signing Branco, the famous Brazilian defender, the MetroStars were trying to untangle themselves from an awkward situation involving Antony De Avila, the Colombian striker who plays for them. De Avila created waves in Colombia with a controversial statement following his country's 1-0 victory over Ecuador in a World Cup qualifying game on Sunday. Shortly after he scored with four minutes left -- at about the same time the MetroStars were losing by 4-0 to Los Angeles at Giants Stadium -- De Avila announced that he was dedicating the goal and Colombia's victory to the country's jailed drug kingpins.
docs.abstract: Antony De Avila, Colombian striker who also plays for MetroStars, created waves in Colombia with controversial statement following his country's recent 1-0 victory over Ecuador in World Cup qualifying game; after he scored, De Avila announced that he was dedicating goal and Colombia's victory to country's jailed drug kingpins, Miguel and Gilberto Rodriguez Orejuela (M)

headline.main: Controversy on Player's Salute to Drug Lords

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    In ''The World Resurrects Che'' (Editorial Notebook, July 20), Tina Rosenberg jumps to an unwarranted conclusion: that if Che Guevara were alive today, ''he would be firmly in the capitalist camp.''

headline.main: Would Che Have Turned Capitalist? Never!
